awd_titl_txt: Development of the Biology Lab Inventory of Critical Thinking for Ecology (Eco-BLIC)
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by developing a new assessment instrument, titled the Biology Lab Inventory of Critical thinking for Ecology or Eco-BLIC, that biology instructors can use to measure undergraduate students' critical thinking skills in the context of ecology data collected from field settings. Critical thinking is defined here as the evidence-based ways in which individuals make decisions about what to trust and what to do. While education research to date has largely focused on student learning from lectures and recitations, there is far less research on the critical thinking learning outcomes that are often stated goals of instructional laboratory and field courses. This unequal balance leaves many open research questions regarding what students are currently learning from these courses, what students could be learning, and how to measure such learning. Furthermore, ecology lab and field courses that help students engage in critical thinking through participation in research projects can be some of the most resource intensive components of a departmental curriculum. They often require specialized facilities, extensive coordination, and occupy a significant amount of student and instructional staff time. These logistical challenges and resources, along with little research to evaluate what critical thinking skills students are learning in these courses, have caused a decline in offerings of authentic laboratory and field ecology courses at the undergraduate level. With the Eco-BLIC, departments will be able to measure potential growth in students' critical thinking skills, which in turn can help them determine how to best argue for and use resources to enhance their ecology laboratory and field-based offerings.

While there are related instruments, no single instrument effectively meets the needs of assessing experimentation-focused critical thinking in undergraduate ecology lab and field courses. The proposed Eco-BLIC instrument will allow the biology education research community to respond to calls to build evidence about laboratory and field course instruction, and to generate new knowledge about student core competencies and difficulties in critical thinking. The design of the Eco-BLIC will build from recent work to develop a Physics Lab Inventory of Critical thinking (PLIC). Based on the design of the PLIC, we will create experimental contexts and suites of questions that probe students' critical thinking skills about ecology field research data. The contexts and questions will be intended to assess a range of students from multiple institutions and will be research-validated following standard procedures, including comparing open- and closed-response versions, interviewing students, and getting feedback from experts. During the question development process, the expert feedback will check the clarity and accuracy of the Eco-BLIC questions. Expert answers will also be used to: 1) develop the scoring scheme, 2) evaluate discrimination of the instrument by comparing differences in undergraduate and expert critical thinking skills, and 3) measure pre/post changes in students' agreement with the expert responses. Pilot versions of Eco-BLIC will be given to students at multiple institution types and we will use a suite of statistical techniques (e.g., reliability coefficients for test-retest stability, item analysis, test analysis, factor and network analysis) to collect evidence of assessment validity and reliability, and to determine the extent to which the questions are able to measure outcomes in various student populations. We will also compare student answers on the PLIC versus the Eco-BLIC to identify and study themes about critical thinking that span multiple disciplines.  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Every year more than 100,000 biology degrees are conferred nationally. Further, non-biology majors will enroll in at least one biology class during their undergraduate program. As outlined in the Vision and Change report, institutions and instructors are working to make biology courses productive for these students regardless of their degree choice or future career paths by integrating core concepts with disciplinary competencies. Although the core concepts of biology are presented in a variety of classroom settings, often the core competencies of biology are introduced through laboratory and field courses, including those that focus on ecology.

 

It is through investigating ecology questions that students often learn several useful scientific skills. These skills include careful attention to study design in order to control confounding variables, how to make inferences, and the importance of distinguishing between correlation and causation. Students also learn that experimental manipulations can sometimes be impossible due to ethical or logistical constraints. In addition, ecological data are often messy, with low R-squared values, small sample sizes, or data types prone to systematic issues that can make drawing conclusions difficult. Finally, from a societal perspective, ecological problems are often politically contentious, and interest groups can bend facts and purport false conclusions from data. Ecology courses, therefore, provide an opportunity to train students in data analysis, evaluation, and critical thinking skills that will be useful to them regardless of their career paths.

 

Intellectual Merit: To evaluate the efficacy of ecology lab and field courses it is necessary to develop response-validated assessment instruments that can be used to explore student learning about the unique aspects of ecology experiments. Here, we developed the Biology Lab Inventory of Critical thinking for Ecology, or Eco-BLIC, which evaluates students’ critical thinking skills in the context of ecology data collected from lab and field settings. The Eco-BLIC was used to evaluate thousands of students’ critical thinking skills over time in a variety of lab and field-based courses at dozens of institutions. 

 

The Eco-BLIC is a freely available, closed-response assessment of undergraduate students' critical thinking in ecology. Using student responses to questions and think-aloud interviews, we demonstrated the effectiveness of the Eco-BLIC at measuring students’ critical thinking skills. We found that while students generally think like experts (i.e., those who hold PhDs in the field) while evaluating what experimental outcomes to trust, students' responses are less expert-like when deciding on what experiments to do next.

 

We also engaged in multidisciplinary research to examine student responses to physics and biology critical thinking questions. We see few differences in the overall approaches students take to answering the questions and that they similarly define critical thinking in both disciplines. However, one key difference is that students perceive physics but not biology to involve quantitative critical thinking skills. Understanding these differences has important implications for college-level biology and physics course instruction, including Introductory Physics for Life Sciences courses.

 

Broader Impacts: In dozens of presentations to national audiences and three publications, we described the development of the Eco-BLIC using tests of validity and reliability, shared additional findings about assessment design, and conducted a scoping-review of the literature on field courses. During the duration of the grant, over 5300 students at 30 institutions took the assessment. At the end of each semester, we send out summary reports of students’ performance on the Eco-BLIC to each instructor who administered the instrument to their students. These reports summarized trends in student answers to the questions and compared student answers to expert responses. To date we have sent out 75 unique summary reports to instructors who shared the Eco-BLIC in their courses and invited instructors to contact us with any questions or feedback they had regarding the data included in these reports. The reports will soon be integrated into an interactive, web-based dashboard, where instructors can explore their students’ performance along different dimensions of critical thinking, compare to a national dataset, and download their data themselves for further exploration.

 

Taken together, this work has contributed a new, freely-available assessment that instructors can use in their courses, information about assessment instrument design, a scoping review about the current state of research on field biology courses, and studies about how biology and physics students approach critical thinking and how it compares to experts. This instrument will continue to broadly support ecology instructors’ evidence-based decision making about their lab and field course instruction beyond the lifetime of the project. Importantly, this work also opens the possibility to develop more critical thinking assessments in additional biology subdisciplines (e.g., genetics, molecular biology) and new disciplines (e.g., chemistry) using similar question formats.
